item.title: Writing in vim with vsplit and multiple windows
item.description:
I imagine a digital writing environment that mimics how I write in my paper notebooks. On paper I use multiple columns, with parallel writing across the columns and the ability to go back and forth rather than just reading up and down. A recent discussion of a three column writing style describes how and why this works.

An approach new to me is to use very large windows in “vim”, with the “vsplit” command to split the screen into three very tall windows. I don’t manage to get a full 80 column width out of each of them, but 65 columns is close enough that it feels like a workable writing environment. Moving between windows isn’t quite as easy as guiding the pen across the printed page, but it’s much easier than trying to do a fancy layout in a markup language.

It’s difficult to translate the writing environment directly to the screen for display. This post will be on the right two-thirds of the blog with a relatively static left sidebar (which no one ever clicks on, but that seems obligatory for the design). At some point I might do a redesign, and then who knows what the left and right context will be.

There was a brief moment when my writing environment was mostly wiki with special purpose (read: hacked in) commands for maintaining a separate sidebar for each file, displayed adjacent to the main text. This was a personal wiki so I didn’t have to negotiate appropriate activity by any other users. The perpetual connected side display allows you to have a little negotiation with yourself about things that aren’t quite ready to put into the main text.

vim is a very powerful environment, perhaps too powerful. Some key combinations have profound and unexpected power over the command buffer, and you get lost. I find it easier to cope with, though, than the even more powerful emacs. I used GNU Emacs for a while in college but never managed to keep up with it, in large part because the strange key combinations of alt-meta-control-coke-bottle would strain my wrists. At least with vim, I can keep my fingers on the home row for the most part.

Writing context is important, and too often lost. You don’t see the right sidebar where I have notes about the Internet of Things and the sorts of interesting equipment that might mount on a sign post. My notes about a mysterious vim “E212” error in the left sidebar are gone.

It looks like the vsplit windows on this particular screen, when filled, hold about 450 words. Fully loaded, that means that a page properly laid out might have more than 1300 words of usable typing space. I could get used to this layout - not just because it lets me see the whole work, but also because it admits a couple of productive distractions.

item.title: Ann Arbor quiet writing escapes
item.description:
Where to go in Ann Arbor to do some quiet writing, without distractions. There are plenty of cafes where there are lots of people around; this list looks for the empty places where you won’t have your attention broken quite so easily.

This is a much easier task in the summer time than it is during the school year, as the students thin out and University buildings are much quieter.

Central Campus:

  • Rackham Building reading rooms, second floor. Very lovely, very quiet, recommended by many.
  • Hatcher Graduate Library study carrels, especially on the higher floors. You’ll have a little room of your own.
  • Law Library reading room.
  • Michigan League, upper floors
  • Museum of Art
  • Palmer Commons, where the upper floors have writing desks
  • Social Work Library
  • Michigan Union first floor reading rooms

Downtown:

  • Ann Arbor City Hall, council chambers (not during a meeting)
  • Sweetwaters, Liberty or Washington St
  • Ann Arbor District Library, third floor (periodicals) or fourth floor (administration)
  • Zingerman’s Next Door, upstairs in one of the smaller rooms
  • Mighty Good Coffee

North side:

  • Matthaei Botanical Gardens
  • Duderstadt Center library, second floor (periodicals)

South side:

  • Ann Arbor Municipal Airport
  • Roos Roast

Ypsilanti

  • Cultivate in Depot Town

Of course, external distractions are only one part of the complex question of “why are no words appearing on the page”. There are some a few tricks that I use to minimize distractions coming from the computer itself.

  • Write in a big ‘vim’ window. Open up Terminal, maximize a window, and then fire up ‘vim’. I’m managing to get 62 lines on the screen without having to squint, and the browser is not on the screen.
  • Go offline. If your writing environment allows, do your writing without a connection to the Internet.
  • If you must stay online, mute notifications. On my Mac that’s a “Do not disturb” setting.

With a big screen up another functional way to avoid a distraction is to keep sitting until the screen is full. It’s not necessary to actually want to keep all of the words that you write - it’s OK to discard some of them in a subsequent editing session - but the self imposed constraint to fill the page all the way to the bottom on a 62 line screen produces a substantial quantity of work in a single sitting.

A useful quality to cultivate is “sitzfleisch”.

The Germans have aptly called Sitzfleisch the ability to spend endless hours at a desk doing grueling work. Sitzfleisch is considered by mathematicians to be a better guage of success than any of the attractive definitions of talent with which psychologists regale us from time to time. Gian-Carlo Rota.

Pull up a seat, open up the screen, start typing. Don’t look up until the page is full. Set yourself a time limit and a word count and aim for that. The time limit can be enforced by parking in a space where your time is limited, which reminds me that I must be going.

item.title: A commonplace reader
item.description:
Sometimes it’s easier and faster to fill a page by quoting from others.

The commonplace book is the annotated scrapbook, carefully collecting bits from other writers with just enough commentary and selection to make them your own. If these were written in this era you’d call it “curation”, though I can only think of that word in the context of “curated meats”, somewhat salty and dry and meant to be preserved for some time.

Anyway, the commonplace book. Why write your own words, when there are so many other good ones already written to quote from? As it is said, though no attribution is reliable,

Immature artists copy, great artists steal.

The artist steal from tonight is Brian Eno, in particular his Oblique Strategies, which I now have as three lines of shell script plus 128 lines of text. A sample, intended to be drawn at random:

Not building a wall but making a brick

As to brick-machines, this from Popular Science

Bricks are fairly easy to make, but in the developing world, traditional fired bricks are sometimes weak and crumble-prone, while cement ones are often unaffordable. The Vermeer BP714 is the first compressed-earth-block machine that makes strong air-dried bricks out of dirt. Its bricks don’t just exceed U.S. cement-code strength requirements—they’re 20 to 30 percent stronger, and cheaper than other machines’ too.

Of course that’s the story you want to tell when someone else has a lot of mud and you have a lot of machine.

The commonplace style of writing allows you to fill a page with text faster, since you’re cutting and pasting it in rather than sweating to find the exact words yourself. The downside is that you might sometimes have to hunt for the correct word, and it will be obvious that it’s someone else’s correct word. There is no question of plagiarism, just of assembly.

The serious crimes in terms of writing are that of plagiarism and copyright violation. (Reality Studio)

So long as we are going down this route, it’s worth rejecting plagiarism as a thought-crime. From Kenneth Goldsmith:

It seems an appropriate response to a new condition in writing: With an unprecedented amount of available text, our problem is not needing to write more of it; instead, we must learn to negotiate the vast quantity that exists. How I make my way through this thicket of information—how I manage it, parse it, organize and distribute it—is what distinguishes my writing from yours.

We make patchworks. Most two word phrases can be easily found on the Internet.

Most two-word phrases are not produced under unpleasant stress, but in interest or excitement. (Penelope Leach, “Babyhood”)

The important thing is to provide the reader with enough information so that the article can be easily found on the References page. (Communication Research Methods in Postmodern Culture)

Lists of real-world materials and their refractive indexes are easily found on the Internet. (Lanier, “Maya Studio Projects Texturing and Writing”)

Retroactively we can construct some level of patchwork that we can crib from, in interest or excitement.

item.title: At Zingermans Coffee for an afternoon of writing
item.description:
A daily coffee and wifi report.

At times I get frustrated by my ability to sit down and produce words on a page. The challenge is not to keep going once I get going, but in the very act of getting started.

I do best at writing when I have a prompting question that allows me to go on and on at least to get to the point where the screen is full and ready to be edited down to size. The prompt doesn’t have to be the words that eventually get onto the page; it’s at least as likely that you discover what you sat down to do only 3⁄4 of the way down the screen, and then’t it’s time to shuffle the page around to save what’s savable and refocus what you had dealt with into a smaller spot.

Prompting questions are fun (and hard). I once wrote for AnnArbor.com, a semi-lovable job which was equal parts delight and horror. The delight was that the prompt only was to keep the phrase “Ann Arbor” in the first paragraph. The horror was the task of reading all of the comments on all of the stories written. Since then, I never read the comments.

It’s easy to be distracted while writing in such a way that the start never happens. Deadlines and word counts have a way of sharpening the mind, and that helps. The trick is to realize that you have to trick yourself sometimes into starting, and once the words start to flow it is not so difficult.

First, there’s all of the other windows that you might have open that have little bubbles protesting that you can’t close them until you empty out that bubble. I don’t want to count how many alternative rounded rectangles there are hiding on-screen that all demand some measure of attention. It’s not just that there are non-zero numbers on the inbox, that’s normal; it’s also that every other communications channel seems to be wide open. To close them you either deal with the system or ignore it.

Next of course since it’s Zingerman’s there’s almost always someone I know to reacquiaint myself with, or someone I don’t know to be introduced to. I’m not sure how they managed to make a non-descript entrance in an industrial park into Grand Central Station, but they did, and I appreciate the effort.

Finally there’s the notifications coming from various systems - Slack, or Facebook, or email. I’d be remiss in not suggesting to myself that I shut them off, but they persist, and because they are handy sometimes I let myself get noise in the upper right hand corner of the screen.

Of late the “screen is full” challenge has gotten harder, since I’m using as big a text window to type into as I can - 60+ lines tall, and more than 200 characters wide. A 500 word essay fits in one column of that page and can easily be seen on a single screen. Divide the screen in two, and 1000 words come to view. What you can do when the whole argument comes into sharp focus, and you can see that the excuses that you are making in the middle of it don’t need to be there.

item.title: Bots are hot - again
item.description:
The title of the post is taken from a 1996 Wired article by Andrew Leonard describing the state of automated systems in the dot-com era.

Web robots – spiders, wanderers, and worms. Cancelbots, Lazarus, and Automoose. Chatterbots, softbots, userbots, taskbots, knowbots, and mailbots. MrBot and MrsBot. Warbots, clonebots, floodbots, annoybots, hackbots, and Vladbots. Gaybots, gossipbots, and gamebots. Skeleton bots, spybots, and sloth bots. Xbots and meta-bots. Eggdrop bots. Motorcycle bull dyke bots.

Bots are hot today in part because natural langauge processing has improved to the point where Google can build hardware to speed up their software algorithms and run their immense training corpuses through it quickly to fine tune their approach. The output of this effort is ASICs that speed up their Tensorflow algorithm for machine learning. Thus Google can safely give away their software, knowing that anyone else running it will use a multiple of the energy that it takes Google to do it.

It’s instructive to look at the changes throughout the years and how bots have co-evolved with the networks and computer systems that they inhabit. Early AIs like ELIZA and PARRY lived on mainframes connected to very slow wide-area networks, and it was years before the two of them talked to each other online. The 1980s and 1990s brought Usenet and the automation that could live on store-and-forward networks. AOL Instant Messenger’s ubiquitous chat met popular culture and the emergence of advertising bots like GooglyMinotaur, which promoted the music of Radiohead.

I’ve been writing what I think is some kind of manuscript about bots and their personalities, a biographical dictionary of emerging intelligences. I’m at about 10,000 words. It’s a challenge to try to corral that much quasi-intelligence onto the page, including trying as best I can to characterize some systems that are known only by people’s memories of them.

item.title: Three column writing style
item.description:
The elements of a three column writing style:

There is a broad center, with sidebars left and right.

The left sidebar is labelled “Do”, and it contains a record of the things that were done; sit in a chair, drink a cup of coffee, do laundry between writing bits, make the bed.

The right sidebar contains snippets or longer of things that were read, since you are expected when writing to have reading materials nearby to crib from or to be inspired by. Tonight I have the Taschen postcardbook “Barkitecture”, and a postcard from Syracuse Cultural Workers on “How to create community”, to guide me along.

This leaves the middle main column for thoughts, impressions; “writing”, not that the other bits are any fewer words on the page.

The challenge overall is how to represent this on the computer screen. When you write in this style, the page can be read top to bottom or left to right or in any diagonal direction, and it will still make some sense. Short of typing words into cells of a spreadsheet, or composing in a monospaced font with exact word counts, it’s hard to recreate precisely.

I’ve always liked writing in the sidebar, sometimes more so than the writing in the middle. Quadrille paper helps to keep the margins aligned.

(Note that the blogging format is essentailly a one-column style with some static sidebars, and I have never managed to compose anything suitable that really captures my notebooks.)

item.title: May Day at Roos Roast with Burroughs and Polya
item.description:

Egg and a shot at Roos Roast.

AVOID GRINDING OVER STEAMING POT.

Drinking the espresso shot, with an increasing titration of milk. Reading Twitter. Sunday a.m. tweeting is good.

Anker battery plugged in to 75% Macbook.

Avantgarde Design postcard book, UM Credit Union pen.

What I was thinking at the time.

Reading a Burroughs interview, on his multicolumn notebooks, cut ups, and fold-ins. Writing technology.

I reread How To Solve It when I am looking for work. Does it work? Is there some better text?

Grand Hotel serving sushi, says Crain’s Detroit. Do they also serve smelt? What happened to the smelt runs?

Brian Kerr writes of the intricate ritual of being dependent on electronica, and the daily or more frequent need to recharge batteries.

Abby Smith Rumsey on prserving history in a digtial age;

Pondering that my digital ephemera are dependent on monthly subscriptions, and could fade in a moment.

Cyberspace, remember that, data gloves and VRML and the metaverse and all that? Yeah. There.

Quotations from any book I take with me.

What is the unknown? What are the data? What is the condition?

The second rule of discovery is to sit tight and wait until you get a bright idea.

Variation of the problem is essential.

Any relation to the adding machine firm?

My grandfather.

The International Style that developed as a result marked the breakthrough of functional design suited to the technical requirements of mass production.

end note

The Burroughvian three column style is very sutiable for the (illeg.) Read across, or down.

item.title: Ann Arbor hydrant flushing maps
item.description:
The City of Ann Arbor has maps showing you where the hydrants are being flushed. If your water turns brown, the most likely cause of it is sediment being disturbed by hydrant flush tests. Run your cold water for a bit until it clears. If it doesn’t clear promptly, call the city. A secondary source of sediment is unexpected water main breaks.

It is possible to get notified of hydrant flushing in your neighborhood, but it’s not easy. The city sends out an email through GovDelivery alerting you that there is hydrant flushing somewhere in the city:

Routine fire hydrant flushing continues in Ann Arbor next week, April 25-29, 2016.

That email contains a link to a news release at

http://www.a2gov.org/news/pages/article.aspx?i=252

which doesn’t say anything about where the flushing is going to take place, except to say that there’s a map. You click on the page that says there’s a map

http://www.a2gov.org/departments/field-operations/Pages/hydrantflush.aspx

and it reiterates that there’s a map, and one more click hopefully finally connects you to the map itself

http://www.a2gov.org/annarborhydflush

That’s three clicks to get to the page, with no hints anywhere along the way about where the hydrant flushing actually is.

If there were ever a reason to put in an embedded map on any of these pages, it would be that people are unlikely to click through three times just in case their neighborhood is affected.

item.title: The incomplete image
item.description:
There’s a great Michelle Shocked song off her Texas Campfire Tapes album called the 4⁄4 Troubador The lyrics you can find don’t capture it all because the song has a prelude of Michelle talking about how most people wouldn’t put together a song that has so many incomplete images and that seemingly stops half way through with all of that unresolved.

“That’s all”

Actually that’s not quite all - I have this song on cassette tape, but you won’t find it on Youtube. Michelle doesn’t believe in Youtube.

“Music is a lot like politics — too important to be left to professionals.”

item.title: Mechanical slaves and the Californian ideology
item.description:
Noted elsewhere, saved here for reference, from

Richard Barbrook and Andy Cameron, THE CALIFORNIAN IDEOLOGY

If human slaves are ultimately unreliable, then mechanical ones will have to be invented. The search for the holy grail of Artificial Intelligence reveals this desire for the Golem a strong and loyal slave whose skin is the colour of the earth and whose innards are made of sand. As in Asimov’s Robot novels, the techno-utopians imagine that it is possible to obtain slave like labour from inanimate machines. Yet, although technology can store or amplify labour, it can never remove the necessity for humans to invent, build and maintain these machines in the first place. Slave labour cannot be obtained without somebody being enslaved.

Read this and then think about Siri, Cortana, “Amy Ingram” and other long-suffering inanimate machines that we imbue so much personality into that some of us unknowingly flirt with a robot because we are so charmed by their devotion.

item.title: Taking a break from Facebook
item.description:
I’m taking a temporary break from Facebook.

You probably won’t read this message in time to switch any of your normal communciations paths with me; indeed, unless I had told you that I was leaving Facebook idle for a while you wouldn’t notice at all.

I’d prefer it if more people were blogging, and more to the point if I were blogging more. I miss the olden days when you could count on people updating their blogs more than once a month and when it made sense to make the rounds of blogrolls. But I suppose that’s just net.nostalgia for the olden days, the same way you might say that Flickr was better the first few years, and oh we don’t have anything quite like the Napster that we once had.

What we do have is Facebook, and plenty of it. A recent story somewhere that I read somewhere (see, this media makes our brains mush) was that people with Facebook accounts are dying, and that the Facebook we know now will be dominated some time soon by memorials to the dead.

Faced with that grim promise, what to do instead? Twitter is my solace, the endless stacatto chatter punctuated by weird Unicode glyphs, with cryptic tendencies and self-contained non-sequiturs.

I’m taking a break. How can you tell? I’m writing again. I don’t write on Facebook, so much as scroll endlessly and leave little obscure comments made out of mostly-remembered lyrics.

item.title: Roos Roast to add downtown Ann Arbor location
item.description:
Roos Roast is adding a downtown Ann Arbor location, due to open spring of 2016. The roastery on Rosewood will expand to a second location on E Liberty St, where Elixir Vitae used to be. Elixir will keep its Maynard St store open.

The interior construction in the store is going well, as far as it’s possible to determine from looking at the permit process and poking my head inside the door. So far the following permits have been pulled, according to the city’s eTrakit system:

BLDG16-0317 for demolition in the existing site, approved 3/7/2016

ELEC16-0449 for internal electrical wiring, approved 4/18/2016; work by Bremray Electrical

HDC16-062 to the Historic District Commission for a sign, applied 4/18/2016

PLUM16-0551 for plumbing, work by Chelsea Plumbing

SIGN16-0050 for an aluminum sign showing a hand holding a cup with the Roos Roast logo, applied 4/18/2016; the sign review is due 5/5/2016. Sign by Prototype Design in Tecumseh.

SOCC16-0024 for sidewalk occupancy, issued 4/21/2016.

The only piece of this process that looks like it could possibly go to a public hearing is the Historic District Commission determination of appropriateness of signage. If this were to be the case, a large orange poster would go up in front of the store to announce the meeting date.

A sign had been approved previously for the site in 2009 when the storefront housed “Organic Bliss”; at that point there was no requirement for anything more than staff approval of the signage. AnnArbor.com’s story about Organic Bliss closing in 2012 has a photo of the storefront at that time.
